newsitem.title: UK: Halifax, A&L lag behind bank sector rally.
newsitem.headline: Halifax, A&L lag behind bank sector rally.

text.p: Shares in Halifax Plc and Alliance & Leicester Plc lagged behind a sharp rally in the bank sector on Tuesday as investors shunned the newly de-mutualised building societies because of stretched valuations, dealers and analysts said.
"Valuations are too high, and mortgage banking growth is slowing. There's a lot of froth in this market," said one analyst.
At 1407 GMT, shares in Halifax were up one penny to 757-1/2. Shares in A&L slipped 3p to 616 while Woolwich Plc shares eased one penny to 299-1/2.

The stunning strength of sterling has drawn foreign investors into UK assets. Investors have snapped up the most liquid shares in banks with reliable earnings - issues that are insulated from the currency's strength.
"No U.S. investor is going to buy something at 17 times earnings," the analyst said of Halifax stock.
A disappointing performance by Woolwich, floated on July 7, also has taken some of the lustre out the former building societies, another analyst added.
HSBC Holdings Plc staged the best performance in the sector and helped lead the FTSE 100 to a new peak on Tuesday.
The shares rose 84-1/2p, or 4.2 percent, to a record 20.85 stg hoisted by a record-setting rally in Hong Kong's Hang Seng index overnight.
Standard Chartered, which also has exposure to Hong Kong, advanced 27p to 1000-1/2.
